thingsToDo.text: Amidst a placid lake and surrounded by trees is the golden Kinkakuji Temple, a Zen temple wrapped in gold leaf, with the top floor gilded both inside and out. It was originally built as a retirement home for a famous shogun, who sanctioned the building to become a temple after his death.

thingsToDo.name: Participate in a tea ceremony
thingsToDo.text: Though tea ceremonies, known as chado or sado, are available all throughout Japan, experiencing one in Kyoto is especially sacred due to its strong Zen Buddhist roots. During a tea ceremony, the cup of tea is prepared artfully and carefully before serving it.

thingsToDo.name: Enjoy a panoramic view of the city at the Kyoto Tower
thingsToDo.text: A modern structure in a city of temples, the Kyoto Tower is the tallest building in Kyoto. Visitors can view panoramic views of the city extending all the way to Osaka. On the platform, telescopes and LED touch screens highlight notable landmarks, so that you can put a name to what you’re seeing. Go at sunset for the best experience.

thingsToDo.name: Climb to the top of Mt. Kurama and relax in the hot springs
thingsToDo.text: About 20 kilometers from the center of Kyoto is Kurama, a quaint town known for its traditional hotels and baths. Travelers can hike to the top of Mt. Kurama to Kurama-dera, an ornate Buddhist temple just above town. Those who want to save their energy for later can even take a cable car halfway up. Past the temple is a steep hiking trail surrounded by old trees with outstretched roots where its common to see songbirds, deer, monkeys, and other wildlife.

thingsToDo.name: Enjoy the Kyoto International Manga Museum
thingsToDo.text: Japanese cartoonists have a unique style of drawing figures for their audience. Manga is created for adults and children alike, and is commonly seen all throughout Japanese pop culture – with a significant history that draws back to the late 19th century.

thingsToDo.name: Smell cherry blossoms at Maruyama Park
thingsToDo.text: Maruyama Park is Kyoto’s best place to view cherry blossoms. In the evening, the central weeping cherry tree is even lit up for a spectacular display. The magical thing about this park is that it has many varieties of cherry blossoms, so visitors can witness a range of color, size, and texture. Enjoy a cup of tea or warm meal under the trees and watch the cranes float by on the nearby pond.

places.name: Osaka
places.description: Osaka is one of the main cities in Japan after Tokyo and is located on the island of Honshu. It is not as traditional or picturesque as other spots in the country like Kyoto, but it is still well worth a visit if you are planning a tour of Japan. Many locals will tell you that Osaka is one of the most laid back cities in the country and the people here are known for their warm hospitality, which means that you will have the chance to learn all about Japanese culture here.

thingsToDo.name: Visit Osaka-jo
thingsToDo.text: Osaka Castle dates from 1583 when it was first built using 100,000 workers to get the finished building. As with many castles in Japan however, it was destroyed and the structure that stands now was built in 1931 and has also been renovated over the years. Despite the fact that the castle is no longer the original, it is still one of the most impressive buildings in Osaka and is located in the middle of a leafy park and is encircled by a charming moat.

thingsToDo.name: Tour Kamigata Ukiyoe Museum
thingsToDo.text: If you want to learn more about traditional art in Osaka then consider a trip to Kamigata Ukiyoe Museum where you can learn all about the art of ukiyoe which is a kind of Japanese print. The prints are made using blocks of wood and the museum itself is styled on a traditional Japanese house.

thingsToDo.name: Explore Sumiyoshi Shrine
thingsToDo.text: Sumiyoshi Shrine has the claim to fame of being one of the oldest Shinto shrines not only in Osaka but also in wider Japan. The shrine was built over 1,800 years ago and it is said to be one of the prettiest Shinto shrines of its kind thanks to its ornate architecture and dainty design features.

thingsToDo.name: Go out in Dotonbori
thingsToDo.text: Dotonbori is known is Osaka as the place to come if you want to go out and enjoy the best of the city. This part of Osaka is the central hub of bars, restaurants and cafes, and you can come here in the evening to enjoy the relaxed atmosphere. Many of the cafes and restaurants here also have their own roof terraces and this means that you can sit out, listen to some live music and look out across twinkling Osaka at the same time.

thingsToDo.name: Try the local food
thingsToDo.text: Osaka is known in Japan for being something of a foodie paradise so if you like to eat then you have come to the right place! Some of the highlights here include the Okonomiyaki which is a kind of pancake made from shredded cabbage which is loaded with a range of toppings, as well as battera which is a style of sushi which features mackerel compressed with rice in a wooden box.

thingsToDo.name: Ride the Tempozan Ferris Wheel
thingsToDo.text: The Tempozan Ferris Wheel is one of the most iconic sights in Osaka and is located on the edge of the scenic Osaka Bay. At one time this would have been the tallest Ferris wheel of its kind in the world and the main attraction here is the chance to take a spin on the wheel and check out the pretty sights across the city.

name: Thailand
description: From glittering temples to gorgeous tropical beaches, Thailand is a fascinating land of culture, history, and charm. There’s plenty to do in this enchanting nation of gilded Buddhas, Royal palaces and the ever-welcoming Thai smile and grace. You could enjoy Bangkok's Siam Square by day and night. Relax on the tropical beaches of Phuket. Try authentic Thai cuisine with only the freshest local ingredients, and spend some up-close time with elephants—the choices are aplenty.
weather: Tropical, with hot, cold and rainy seasons.
bestTimeToVisit: November-early April, when it’s cooler and dry.

thingsToDo.name: Head to Phi Phi islands
thingsToDo.text: A great getaway for beach relaxation as well as diving, snorkeling, kayaking, and other marine recreation.

thingsToDo.name: Get cultured at Chiang Mai
thingsToDo.text: Explore temples dating to the 1300s, and a night bazaar that stretches across several city blocks for a culturally-rich experience.

thingsToDo.name: Go shopping at the Floating Market
thingsToDo.text: Ride a boat to this Bangkok market, where vendor boats sell everything from fresh fruits and flowers to clothing and souvenirs.

thingsToDo.name: Have fun with elephants
thingsToDo.text: Elephant Hills' Jungle Safari is fun for everyone. Enjoy taking care of Asian elephants, including washing, feeding, and watching them roam free.

thingsToDo.name: Explore Bangkok's Wat Pho temple
thingsToDo.text: Immerse yourself in the ancient past and marvel at the famed golden Reclining Buddha.

places.name: Bangkok
places.description: Welcome to Bangkok—the sprawling, vibrant capital city of the Kingdom of Thailand. Here action and adventure await you at every turn. Whether you take a tuk tuk across town or the longtail boat through the floating market. Bathe and feed Asian elephants or marvel at golden hued temples and palaces. Indulge in local dishes at the night market or haute cuisine at rooftop restaurants, Bangkok is bustling with activity by day and night.

thingsToDo.name: Check out the Floating Market
thingsToDo.text: Ride a boat to this Bangkok market, where vendor boats sell everything from fresh fruits and flowers to clothing and souvenirs.

thingsToDo.name: Explore Bangkok's Wat Pho temple
thingsToDo.text: Immerse yourself in the ancient past and marvel at the famed golden Reclining Buddha.

thingsToDo.name: Get a bargain at the night market
thingsToDo.text: Shop, eat, drink, and have fun at the Suan Lum Night Bazaar, which boasts more than 2,000 stalls.

thingsToDo.name: Experience the nightlife
thingsToDo.text: From swanky rooftop bars and lively nightclubs to hip cocktail bars, no visit to Bangkok would be complete without a glimpse of its famous nightlife.

thingsToDo.name: Tour the Grand Place
thingsToDo.text: With its beautiful architecture and intricate detail, it’s been the home of the Thai King, the Royal court and the government for 150 years.

places.name: Chiang Mai
places.description: Chiang Mai blends ancient traditions with modern design and cuisine. Those with an interest in Buddhist practice can join the locals as they give alms to the temple monks or visit the International Buddhist Center at Wat Phra That Doi Suthep with its chanting and meditation services. For a more rustic temple experience, journey to the forest temple of Wat Umong. Then, browse the colorful Chiang Mai Night Bazaar. Take a walk on the wild side at the Elephant Nature Park.

thingsToDo.name: Browse the Chiang Mai Night Bazaar
thingsToDo.text: Search for the perfect souvenir at this bustling night bazaar that runs from sundown until late into the night.

thingsToDo.name: Go on a Retreat at the International Buddhist Centre
thingsToDo.text: Visit the Wat Phra That Doi Suthep and marvel at the temple’s golden spires, or delve more deeply into Buddhist ways with a retreat that includes lunch with the monks, meditation, chanting, and discussions.

thingsToDo.name: Visit the Elephants at the Elephant Nature Park
thingsToDo.text: Support the work at the Elephant Nature Park, an elephant rescue and rehabilitation center.

thingsToDo.name: Choose Your Temple
thingsToDo.text: There are over 300 temples across the city. Wat Chedi Luang is home to the revered Emerald Buddha, and Wat Phra Singh is resplendent with its lavish mosaics.

thingsToDo.name: Check out the Art Scene
thingsToDo.text: Chiang Mai boasts a bustling creative scene with modern day galleries and cosmopolitan restaurants.

name: Brazil
weather: In general, Brazil is a year-round destination with temperatures rarely dip below 20°C (68°F), apart from in the mountains and southern regions. The climate varies from hot and dry in the arid interior to humid and sticky in the tropical rainforests of the Amazon jungle.
description: Brazil boasts more than 70 national parks and dozens of monuments, including one of the Seven New Wonders of the World – Christ the Redeemer, in Rio de Janeiro. Together, these attractions create one of the most appealing and exciting destinations in South America. People come from every corner of the world to discover the superlative coastline, sprawling metropolises and thick jungles, which are home to monkeys, jaguars and river dolphins. The vast Brazilian landscape holds many prized spots, yet the places below are some of the very best destinations in the country.
bestTimeToVisit: Overall, the months of September and October are the best time to vacation in Brazil, as you will avoid the major holiday periods as well as the chilly southern winter and the rainy season in the Pantanal

thingsToDo.name: See the Cristo Redentor and Corcovado, Rio de Janeiro
thingsToDo.text: With arms outstretched 28 meters, as if to encompass all of humanity, the colossal Art Deco statue of Christ, called Cristo Redentor (Christ the Redeemer), gazes out over Rio de Janeiro and the bay from the summit of Corcovado.

thingsToDo.name: Sugar Loaf, Rio de Janeiro
thingsToDo.text: The easily recognized emblem of Rio de Janeiro, the rounded rock peak of Sugar Loaf juts out of a tree-covered promontory, rising 394 meters above the beaches and city. Its summit is one of the first places to visit for tourists, for views of Rio and the harbor, and for the thrill of riding suspended in a cable car between Sugar Loaf and the Morro da Urca, a lower peak from which a second cableway connects to the city.

thingsToDo.name: Visit the Iguaçu Falls
thingsToDo.text: At the point where Brazil, Paraguay, and Argentina meet, the Iguaçu river drops spectacularly in a semicircle of 247 waterfalls that thunder down into the gorge below. Just above the falls, the river is constricted to one-fourth of its usual width, making the force of the water even stronger.

thingsToDo.name: Experience the Carnaval in Rio de Janeiro
thingsToDo.text: Few shows match Rio's pre-Lenten Carnaval (Carnival) extravaganza for color, sound, action, and exuberance. Make no mistake, this is not just another rowdy street party, but a carefully staged showpiece, where spectators can watch the parades of competing samba dancers from a purpose-built stadium designed by none other than Brazil's best-known architect, Oscar Niemeyer.

thingsToDo.name: Amazon rain forests
thingsToDo.text: About 20 kilometers southeast of Manaus, the dark Rio Negro waters meet the light muddy water of the Rio Solimões, flowing side by side for about six kilometers before mixing as the Amazon. Boat trips from Manaus take you to this point, called Encontro das Aguas, meeting of the waters. Other boat trips take you into the heart of the rain forests and the network of rivers, channels, and lakes formed by the three rivers. In the Rio Negro, the Anavilhanas Islands form an archipelago with lakes, streams, and flooded forests that offer a full cross-section of the Amazonian ecosystem.

places.name: Rio de Janeiro
places.description: Striking coastlines and exotic forests, thriving nightlife and mesmerizing samba schools – these are just some of the unique elements of Rio de Janeiro, a city with a startling identity unlike any other in the world.

thingsToDo.name: Museum of Tomorrow
thingsToDo.text: One of the 2016 Olympics’ most successful legacies, this groundbreaking science museum poses big questions about mankind’s future, inside an extraordinary neo-futurist building.

thingsToDo.name: Christ the Redeemer
thingsToDo.text: You’ll catch glimpses of this 98-feet-tall figure all around Rio, but don’t miss out on ascending Mount Corcovado to admire the iconic statue up-close.

thingsToDo.name: Take the gondola up Sugarloaf Mountain
thingsToDo.text: Sugarloaf Mountain is the large peak you’ll see in just about every photo of Rio de Janeiro, and taking the gondola to the top is one of the best attractions in Rio de Janeiro. Once at the top, you can wander around and enjoy the views and even a meal or drink

thingsToDo.name: Copacabana Beach
thingsToDo.text: It’s the most famous beach in the world and a trip to Rio wouldn’t be complete without spending at day at Copacabana. This four km iconic beach is filled with energy and excitement. Vendors and restaurants line the sand and a wide paved pathway along the road makes for an easy stroll.

thingsToDo.name: Helicopter Scenic Flight
thingsToDo.text: If there is one city you should do a scenic flight in this world, it is Rio. Rio’s landscape is spectacular with huge mountains framing the city. With a blend of urban sprawl, colourful hillside favelas, jungle, ocean, and beaches, this is one of the most beautiful cities on earth and a helicopter tour lets you truly take in the scope and scale of Rio’s landscape.

places.name: Sao Paulo
places.description: The largest city in Brazil, Sao Paulo (or Sampa as it is also often called), offers an intense cultural experience. Tropical plants, charismatic people, and lively, bright colors, sounds and scents surround every traveler here, from the moment they step from the plane. It is a melting pot city, and has large, integrated populations of Italian and Japanese cultures among others. This fusion of culture has created beautiful combination art, culinary scene, and music that are well worth exploring.

thingsToDo.name: Sao Paulo Cathedral
thingsToDo.text: This is the largest church in the city (but not the state) of Sao Paulo, and can seat 8,000 people. It is a large-domed 20th century cathedral of the neo-gothic style, and was constructed using over 800 tons of marble.

thingsToDo.name: Museu do Futebol
thingsToDo.text: The ultimate museum for football (soccer) fans, the Museu do Futebol offers both traditional exhibits as well as video and interactive displays. From information on famous players and famous games to basic instruction on how the game is played, the museum has things for people at every level of fandom, and even those considering becoming fans.

thingsToDo.name: Avenida Paulista
thingsToDo.text: The 2.8 km (1.7 miles) long Paulista Avenue was originally a residential street filled with large, ornate mansions belonging to coffee barons. Many of these were torn down in the 1950’s, and replaced with large, multi-story buildings. It remains a center of luxury and business, and is much like Park Avenue Meets Wall Street in New York City. Today, many of Sao Paulo’s major banks make their headquarters here, in addition to some of the finest prep schools in the country.

thingsToDo.name: Ibirapuera Park
thingsToDo.text: Sampa’s answer to Central Park, Ibirapuera Park serves as a major recreational site and is one of the main tourist attractions in Sao Paulo. It has paths for walking and jogging, bikeways, woods, lakes, sport courts and areas for relaxation that attract city residents of all ages.

places.name: Salvador
places.description: Located in the great state of Bahia, Salvador is a city filled with culture, history, and food. If you’re planning a trip there, you’re in luck; there are so many fun things to do in Salvador, no matter what type of traveler you are.

thingsToDo.name: Farol da Barra Beach
thingsToDo.text: The Farol da Barra Beach is one of the most popular tourist destination in Salvador, Brazil. It offers a panoramic view of the ocean which, in turn, is simply a treat to the eyes. It is simply one of the best destinations to visit for all the tourists who are fond of witnessing nature in all her glory.

thingsToDo.name: Sao Francisco Church and Convent
thingsToDo.text: The Sao Francisco Church and Convent is a great place to visit in Salvador. The architectural style is indeed a unique one and it is simply great to witness. The design in the interior portion of the church is splendid and it never fails to excite the tourists. It is also the richest church in Latin America.

thingsToDo.name: Casa do Rio Vermelho
thingsToDo.text: The Casa do Rio Vermelho is one of the major tourist destinations in Salvador. It is a storehouse of art and is responsible for attracting tourists from all parts of the nation. The jaw-dropping architecture of the Casa do Rio Vermelho is simply a joy to witness. It houses many ancient pictures, arts, and sculptures which can simply take the tourists by surprise.

thingsToDo.name: Santo Antonio da Barra Fort and Nautical Museum
thingsToDo.text: The Santo Antonio da Barra Fort and Nautical Museum reveals the history of Portuguese exploration in the fifteenth and the sixteenth centuries. The museum contains many historical artifacts which were once a part of an ancient ship that sank in the bay around the seventeenth century, only to be found three-hundred years later. There is also a lighthouse named Barra Lighthouse that provides wonderful scenic views of the ocean.

name: Colombia
weather: Colombia's weather offers all four seasons and they remain generally unchanged throughout the year due to Colombia's proximity to the equator.
description: Colombia has something that will please most travelers, from sandy beaches of the Caribbean and Pacific coasts, to the Andes Mountains and the Amazon rainforests. Its heritage reflects the culture of its indigenous peoples as well as the Spanish who began settling here in the early 15th century.
bestTimeToVisit: The best time to visit Colombia is during the summer months of July and August and the winter months of December and January. These months have some of the lowest rainfall of the year.

thingsToDo.name: Walk Old Cartagena
thingsToDo.text: Designated as a UNESCO World Heritage site in 1984, walking through the historic city center of Cartagena continues to be one of the top things to do in Colombia for travelers from around the world. As you walk the streets or, perhaps, take a carriage ride instead, you can't help but feel transported back in time.

thingsToDo.name: Relax in Parque Tayrona
thingsToDo.text: Located on the Caribbean coast about six hours east of Cartagena, Parque Tayrona is a relatively undeveloped national park where the jungle meets secluded beaches.

thingsToDo.name: Party in Medellin
thingsToDo.text: Enjoy the constant Spring-like weather of Medellin with a night out on the town. While Parque Lleras is the central nightlife district (referred to locally as La Zona Rosa), there are plenty of other options too. Barrio Colombia, Las Palmas, La 70, and La 33 all feature a variety of nightclubs (discotecas) for travelers to party with the locals.

thingsToDo.name: Go Horseback Riding in Valle de Cocora
thingsToDo.text: The Valle de Cocora is a national park situated in the center of Colombia's coffee-growing region. The valley is home to the world's tallest palm tree, the wax palm, which is also the national tree of Colombia. Horseback riding in Valle de Cocora offers a fun way to experience the region's natural beauty.

thingsToDo.name: Learn to Salsa in Cali
thingsToDo.text: Widely considered one of the top salsa dancing cities in the world, Cali is home to some of the country's top professional dancers.

places.name: Cartagena
places.description: One of the most gorgeous, romantic, and colorful cities in the world, Cartagena is packed with history, friendly Colombians, and of course, tourists. The walled city is made up of pastel colonial buildings lined with flowers, cobblestone streets, horse carriages, and plenty of restaurants and boutiques to satisfy all of its many visitors.

thingsToDo.name: Explore the Old City
thingsToDo.text: Most tourists will stay in the old city of Cartagena, which includes the neighborhoods of Centro, San Diego, and Getsemani, and you should too. Here you’ll be close to the most historical parts of the city and its picturesque streets, particularly within the walled city (La Ciudad Amurallada), an UNESCO World Heritage Site.

thingsToDo.name: Castillo de San Felipe de Barajas
thingsToDo.text: This might be the most incredible fortress ever built by the Spanish in any of their colonies and it’s a landmark within the city of Cartagena. Construction began in 1639, and it’s never been taken despite numerous attempts to attack the city. There are tunnels within it specifically designed to allow even small sounds to travel well so that any intruders would be detected easily.

thingsToDo.name: Street Food Tour
thingsToDo.text: While you should definitely pick up some cheese-filled arepas and fresh lemonade from the food vendors in the plazas, you might want to sign up for a street food tour to taste even more local dishes. With a guide you’ll get to try things from carts, alleyways, and shops you’d never find on your own.

thingsToDo.name: Visit a Mud Volcano
thingsToDo.text: El Totumo is a small volcano containing thick bubbling mud that you can bathe in and it’s located just outside of Cartagena. You climb inside the hill-like vat where you’ll float in the mud and even have the option of getting a quick massage.

thingsToDo.name: Islas del Rosario
thingsToDo.text: A beautiful day trip while in Cartagena, the Islas del Rosario are 27 islands located in the crystal clear Caribbean waters just off the coast of the city. They’re filled with coral reefs that serve as a natural habitat for tons of aqualife, and you can spend a day here boating, swimming, or snorkeling.

places.name: Bogota
places.description: Don’t be intimidated by the sprawling, bustling city of Bogotá. Colombia’s capital is truly historic and packed with touristy things to do, but it’s also got a cool, hip, and even chic side to it as well. From its weekly Ciclovía bike route through the streets to its upscale neighborhoods filled with great restaurants, parks, and excellent nightlife, Bogotá is a real cosmopolitan city.

thingsToDo.name: Stroll Through La Candelaria
thingsToDo.text: This is probably the first thing tourists do in Bogotá because La Candelaria the historic center of the city. Follow the cobblestone streets past colorful Spanish colonial buildings and university halls, check out the street art, and pop into a few cathedrals.

thingsToDo.name: The Gold Museum
thingsToDo.text: Bogotá’s Museo del Oro is the most popular (and possibly the most interesting) museum in the city, and it’s home to more than 30,000 pieces of gold. There are three floors filled with artifacts collected from Colombia’s pre-Hispanic cultures, each focusing on a different theme. Learn how these people discovered, mined, and then worked the metals, making jewelry, masks, bowls, offerings, and armor.

thingsToDo.name: Climb Monserrate
thingsToDo.text: Walk the steep steps up the hill (or take the funicular) to this incredible viewpoint of sprawling Bogotá.

thingsToDo.name: Plaza Bolívar
thingsToDo.text: Head to the center of this capital city to see where government business gets done. This sprawling, pigeon-filled plaza is home to Colombia’s Palace of Justice, the Capitol Building, the Cathedral of Bogotá, and the city mayor’s office.

thingsToDo.name: The Salt Cathedral of Zipaquira
thingsToDo.text: One of the most popular day trips from Bogota, the Salt Cathedral is located in the town of Zipaquirá about an hour outside the city. This whole cathedral was carved deep underground in a salt mine, and it contains alcoves for worshipping and beautifully lit crosses.

thingsToDo.name: Take a Bicycle Tour of the City
thingsToDo.text: While it wouldn’t seem like the best thing to do in a big, bustling city, bike tours of Bogota are really popular. They’re also an excellent way to see a few neighborhoods that are rather spread out and some you wouldn’t stop by on your own.

places.name: Medellin
places.description: The second city of Colombia, Medelliin has transformed itself perhaps more than any other city in the world. Though its violent, tumultuous past is well-known, today the city is modern, innovative, and just generally lovely. Nicknamed the “City of Eternal Spring” for its nearly perfect weather, you’ll find plenty of parks and plazas where you can enjoy the sunshine with a fresh juice from a street food vendor and a couple of empanadas.

thingsToDo.name: Museo de Antioquia
thingsToDo.text: A former city hall turned museum, this place houses a great collection of works by Fernando Botero. He’s one of Colombia’s most famous artists, and he had a penchant for painting all things chubby. Guides recommend starting on the top floor with his earlier pieces and making your way down to see his evolution as an artist.

thingsToDo.name: Take the Metrocable Up to Parque Arvi
thingsToDo.text: The metro and metrocable system of Medellín has received lots of praise for bringing a city of many different neighborhoods together. You can get all over the city with your metro ticket, and if you want to venture up for great views and fresh air, pay a little more to take the metrocable from Santo Domingo to Parque Arvi.

thingsToDo.name: The Botanical Gardens
thingsToDo.text: A natural oasis in the center of Medellin, they city’s botanical gardens contain more than 1,000 species of wildlife and 4,500 flowers. There’s a butterfly garden, a cactus garden, and a huge collection of orchids. Entry is free and you can go explore the area to find critters or just lie on the grass in the sun with a book.

thingsToDo.name: Parque Explora
thingsToDo.text: Everybody loves Parque Explora, even adults and those folks without kids. It’s an interactive science museum combined with South America’s largest freshwater aquarium. There are over 300 interactive exhibits housed in the building’s four red cubes, plus a planetarium, 3D auditorium, and a television studio.

thingsToDo.name: Casa de la Memoria
thingsToDo.text: This museum is both upsetting, enlightening, and informative, and it’s the place to go if you want more insight on Colombia’s dramatic and violent history. From drug cartels and gangs to a terrible civil war, Casa de la Memoria aims to amplify the voices of victims and preserve their history so that we might learn more about it and avoid these pitfalls in the future.

thingsToDo.name: Parque Lleras
thingsToDo.text: Poblado is one of the biggest hotspots for nightlife in Medellin, and for locals and tourists alike, Parque Lleras is often the place where you start out the night. It’s just a little park filled with trees where you’ll find vendors selling art by day and crowds of folks drinking by night. The park is surrounded by bars, restaurants, and clubs, plus it’s close to many of the hostels in the area, so there’s always young people around.

name: Chile
description: Most of the guidebooks will tell you to take your time with Chile.  It’s made for slow adventure and best suited for those who travel with a heart and mind open to experiencing the moment. Chile is uniquely shaped, long and narrow, which can make travelling the country a little challenging. With over 4,000km from one end to the other, you can expect long and always interesting bus rides on your way to explore deserts, fertile valleys, volcanoes, lakes, fjords, glaciers, the Andes mountain range, dunes, and incredible coastline.
weather: It is warm all year round. There is a very large daily range of temperate, up to 30 degrees celsius. Central Chile has a mediterranean type climate with long, hot summers and cool, wet winters.
bestTimeToVisit: The best time to visit Chile depends on the region you’re traveling to. October to March are the warmest and most accessible months for visitors heading to Patagonia, in the south of the country. This is summer in the Southern Hemisphere and the weather is very pleasant, with warm temperatures of around 72°F.

thingsToDo.name: Valparaiso
thingsToDo.text: One of the most unique cities in Chile is Valparaiso.  Climbing up the sides of 42 hills, the city has a bohemian vibe that everyone loves.  There are several funiculars that take you up and down various hills so that you can enjoy the view and the many colourful houses at the top.

thingsToDo.name: Torres Del Paine
thingsToDo.text: You really can’t miss the granite pillars of Torres del Pain, or the Tower of Paine.  They rise more than 2000m over the Patagonian steppe and dominate what is possibly the most majestic national park in all of South America.

thingsToDo.name: Santiago
thingsToDo.text: The capital and largest city in Chile is Santiago.  It sits in a valley surrounded by the breathtaking snow capped Andes Mountains.  Locals will tell you that Santiago IS Chile, and it really won’t take long before you agree.

thingsToDo.name: The Lake District
thingsToDo.text: If you want nature, Chile’s lake district is the place to go. Alerce (Larch) forests, volcanoes capped with snow, fabulous mountain lakes, traditional folklore and handicrafts, and year-round outdoor adventure can all be found here.

places.name: Santiago
places.description: Santiago de Chile, more commonly known as just Santiago, was founded by the Spanish in 1541, and has served as Chile’s capital since the colonial days. It’s a bustling city of more than six million people, but you’ll still find traces of its heritage in the colonial and 19th century neoclassical buildings.

thingsToDo.name: La Moneda
thingsToDo.text: La Moneda, also known “Coin Palace” because it used to be a mint, is where the president of Chile has his offices. Several other key government officials also have offices in the neoclassical structure that takes up a whole block in downtown Santiago.

thingsToDo.name: Gran Torre Santiago
thingsToDo.text: The Gran Torre Santiago towers over Santiago and is so high it can be seen from just about anywhere in the city. At 64 stories high, it is the largest skyscraper in Latin America and the highest occupied floor in the Southern Hemisphere. It’s 300 meters (984 feet) high and has six basements.

thingsToDo.name: Cerro Santa Lucia
thingsToDo.text: Cerro Santa Lucia is a hill in central Santiago that represents the remains of a 15-million-year-old volcano. The hill was originally called Huelen but was renamed in 1543 in honor of Santa Lucia when the Spanish conquistadors took the hill. Over the centuries it’s been home to a fort or two, and many dissidents, who either weren’t Roman Catholic or other or others considered unworthy. The hill was remodeled in the 19th century. Today you’ll find a park, statuary, fountains and a castle that has been remodeled into an events center. You’ll also find some great views of Santiago.

thingsToDo.name: Santiago Metropolitan Cathedral
thingsToDo.text: Where earlier cathedrals in Santiago have been destroyed by earthquakes, the Santiago Metropolitan Cathedral has stood on the Plaza de Armas for more than 260 years. Construction first began in 1748 and the cathedral has dominated the square ever since. The stone neoclassical cathedral is considered one of the best examples of religious architecture in South America.

thingsToDo.name: Cerro San Cristobal
thingsToDo.text: Cerro San Cristobal is a hill in northern Santiago that rises over the city, providing some pretty great views. Spanish conquistadors named it for Saint Christopher. At the top you’ll find an observatory and a statue of the Virgin Mary, part of a sanctuary dedicated to the Immaculate Conception. Pope John Paul II blessed the Santiago at a small chapel at the sanctuary; there’s also an amphitheater where masses are held. Cerro San Cristobal also is home to Santiago’s biggest park, Santiago Metropolitan Park; the Chilean national zoo; a Japanese garden and two swimming pools.

places.name: Easter Island
places.description: Easter Island is famous for its mysterious background and the Moai statues that accompany it. A plethora of theories surround the origins and construction of these giant, monolithic stone statues, but the truth is that they are the legacy left behind by the Rapa Nui civilization that once inhabited the island.

thingsToDo.name: See The Moais at Rano Raraku National Park
thingsToDo.text: This is the main attraction on Easter Island and the one place you shouldn’t miss. This was the main moai quarry and the place where you’ll see them in all their glory and in all stages of production. In fact, about half of the moai of Easter Island are located in this national park. The Moai are monolithic human statues carved between 1,250 and 1500 AD and are considered to be the “living faces” of deified ancestors. They look inland towards the clan that created them as a sign of protection.

thingsToDo.name: Watch The Sunrise From Tongariki
thingsToDo.text: Here you’ll see its 15 moai statues stand next to each other on an Ahu (ceremonial platform) facing inland as you see the orange sun rise right behind them, creating a shadowy silhouette out of the statues.

thingsToDo.name: Relax at Anakena Beach
thingsToDo.text: Anakena is one of the best beaches on the island, and it is easily accessible. It is a small beach, but that doesn’t matter since there aren’t a lot of people on Easter Island.

thingsToDo.name: See The Ancient Petroglyphs At Papa Vaka
thingsToDo.text: While not a vast legacy, there are still traces of Rapa Nui petroglyphs all around the island, with some of the most important ones found in Papa Vaka, Ana Kai Tangata, and Orongo. These petroglyphs often depict several marine scenes that include fishing, the use of canoes, and various marine animals. Part of the daily life of the Rapa Nui.

thingsToDo.name: Hike To The Top Of Terevaka
thingsToDo.text: Easter Island doesn’t have mountains, they are more like pronounced volcanic hills. Still, it is fun to hike these volcanoes, even if the highest one, Terevaka Volcano, is only 507 meters above sea level. Being the highest point on the island, from there you can get a perfect 360-degree view of all Easter Island.

name: Egypt
description: Magnificent monuments, ancient wonders, boundless sandy deserts, the mighty Nile, and the chaotic allure of Cairo are just some of the many things that make Egypt a classic travel destination. From the mystery of the Pyramids and the imposing Great Sphinx of Giza to the turquoise waters of the Red Sea and the endless sand dunes of the Sahara, Egypt’s landscapes are incredibly inspiring.
weather: Mostly hot and dry, temperatures may vary by region.
bestTimeToVisit: October-April, when temperatures are cooler but still pleasantly warm.

thingsToDo.name: Tour the Pyramids and the Sphinx
thingsToDo.text: Wander and wonder around the Great Pyramids and Sphinx of Giza. Venture out into the desert plateau for the best views of all three pyramids.

thingsToDo.name: Learn a little history in Luxor
thingsToDo.text: Known as the 'World's Largest Open-Air Museum,' Luxor features famous historical temples and the Valleys of the Kings & Queens.

thingsToDo.name: Head to the old city - Coptic Cairo
thingsToDo.text: Several centuries old, this part of Cairo has ancient churches and twisting alleyways with beautiful mosaics and woodwork.

thingsToDo.name: Go on a white desert safari
thingsToDo.text: Take a 4x4 into the White Desert National Park, and witness a region of brilliant-white rock formations.

places.name: Cairo
places.description: Headlined by the infamous World Wonder, the architectural marvel that is the Great Pyramids of Giza, Cairo is one of the most fascinating cities in the world. It’s a city of contrasts, where old and new stand side by side, where alive and deceased share land (in the so-called City of the Dead), and where luxurious hotels stand alongside cramped (yet vibrant) souks.

thingsToDo.name: Explore the massive Cairo Citadel
thingsToDo.text: Built in 1176, the Cairo Citadel has a coveted claim to fame as the largest medieval fortress in the world. Following a diverse history of medieval warfare, the stone fortress, now open to visitors, houses four main mosques — the beautiful more modern Mosque of Muhammad Ali, otherwise known as the Alabaster Mosque, the 14th-century Al-Nasir Muhammad Mosque, the Ottoman-style Mosque of Sulayman Pasha, and the lesser-known Mosque of al-‘Azab.

thingsToDo.name: Visit a world wonder — the Giza Pyramids
thingsToDo.text: Standing at a peak of 138 meters tall, no other site in Egypt draws the masses quite like Giza’s Pyramids — the only remaining Wonder of the Ancient World. These three colossal structures (the Great Pyramid of Khufu, Khafre’s Pyramid and Menkaure) have attracted millions of annual visitors since their discovery. They are evidence of the incredible skill and innovation that went into ancient engineering.

thingsToDo.name: Snap a selfie with the Great Sphinx of Giza
thingsToDo.text: Within walking distance of the infamous pyramids (and therefore often combined into the same tour), the 4,500-year-old Sphinx of Giza is another ancient wonder worthy of postcards and millions of travel selfies

thingsToDo.name: Get lost in the Egyptian Museum
thingsToDo.text: An unmissable attraction for history and archeology buffs alike, this downtown Cairo attraction is just next to the Nile. It boasts the world’s largest and most comprehensive collection of Pharaonic history.

places.name: Luxor
places.description: Luxor is one of the most ancient cities in Egypt. For many thousands of years, this southern region of the country was home to the most famous Kings and Queens in Egyptian history.

thingsToDo.name: Go to the Luxor Museum
thingsToDo.text: Start your journey to Luxor with a trip to the Luxor Museum, where you’ll be able to learn all about the region’s long and ancient history before you start exploring the multitude of archaeological sites.

thingsToDo.name: Contemplate History at the Luxor Temple
thingsToDo.text: Take a quick walk south along the River Nile and you’ll soon arrive at one of the city’s most impressive ancient sites, the Luxor Temple. You’ll quickly realize just why the city is said to be one of the world’s greatest open-air museums, and that’s down to the fact that archaeological sites in Luxor are literally in the city center.

thingsToDo.name: See the Massive Columns at Karnak
thingsToDo.text: If you walk north along the Nile River from the Luxor Museum, then you’ll come to what is perhaps Luxor’s most famous temple complex, Karnak. Visiting Karnak is one of the best things to do in Luxor because this ancient religious site is one of the most important in Egpyt. The Karnak complex is huge and you’ll find a separate museum on site too, the Karnak Open-Air Museum, where you can enjoy a wealth of information and artifacts.

thingsToDo.name: Learn About Mummies at the Mummification Museum
thingsToDo.text: It’s not always high up on lists of the best things to do in Luxor, but while you’re exploring the museums and temple complexes in the center of the city, you’ll want to pop into the fascinating Mummification Museum too.

thingsToDo.name: Explore the Valley of the Kings
thingsToDo.text: The Valley of the Kings is one of the most iconic archaeological sites in Egypt, and it’s a must-visit when you are in Luxor. The Valley of the Kings, while being a dramatic outdoor attraction in its own right, is iconic because this is where Egyptian kings chose to have their lavish tombs and burial chambers built. Many have been opened, including that of Tutankhamun, and it’s in the Valley of the Kings where modern Egyptology really began to be popularised.

thingsToDo.name: Don’t Forget the Valley of the Queens
thingsToDo.text: The Valley of the Queens is the next valley along from the Valley of the Kings, and as the name might suggest, this is where the Ancient Egyptian Queens were buried in their own lavish burial chambers. There hasn’t been as much excavation here as has been done in the Valley of the Kings, but it’s equally as dramatic and just as important. Not quite as many of the tombs and archaeological sites are open to the public though.

places.name: Hurghada
places.description: With the crystalline waters of the Red Sea to the east and the sands of Egypt’s vast desert to the west, Hurghada attracts vacationers from across the globe who want to relax on its endless beaches, explore its spectacular dive sites, and take day trips to the historic cities along the Nile River.

thingsToDo.name: Go Diving in the Caves of the Careless Reef
thingsToDo.text: The appeal of this dive site is self-explanatory: it is a technicolour vision of coral forests wriggling with fish – tuna, jacks and even the occasional hammerhead shark. It’s best known – and loved – among divers, for the large population of giant morays lurking in the depths. Two coral towers brushing the water surface delineate the reef, and the chasm between, about 16m (53ft) deep, is your playground.

thingsToDo.name: Visit the Abdel-Moneim Riad Mosque
thingsToDo.text: It’s dubbed the Big Mosque by all who know it, and it’s clear why: its impressive architecture stops passersby in their tracks. Its looks are classically and elegantly Islamic: the arches, domes and hallways are laced with delicate carvings, and the minarets can be seen from miles (kilometres) away. Every day, you’ll hear the call to prayer resonating from within the walls, drifting atmospherically over Hurghada – a reminder you’re in amazing Egypt.

thingsToDo.name: Watch the sunset at the Hurghada Marina Boulevard
thingsToDo.text: Evenings in Hurghada inevitably end with a stroll along the Marina Boulevard. Here, multi-million dollar yachts glint in the late light, floating on transparent waters. You’ll be among visitors from all around the world – and everyone is in awe of the setting.

thingsToDo.name: Marvel at sand sculptures at See Sand City
thingsToDo.text: This open-air museum, just outside Hurghada centre, has two distinct concepts. One focus is on historical and mythological art, borne out in ancient sand sculptures that depict various stories and celebrated military leaders among legendary characters. Contrastingly, there’s Wonderland Art, a display of Walt Disney statues and figures from children’s stories.

thingsToDo.name: Learn to windsurf or kitesurf
thingsToDo.text: If you’re the type who can’t idle on holiday, wiggling your toes in the sand, try learning to windsurf or kitesurf for a breath of fresh air. Whichever activity you sign up for, Hurghada is one of the best locations in the world for beginners.

name: South Africa
weather: Mostly temperate, though temperatures vary by region and season.
bestTimeToVisit: All year round. May-September for Safari. November-February for birdwatching. July-November for whale-watching.
description: South Africa is a country unlike any other. From the world’s best safaris, to the most dramatic landscapes and amazing history and culture, this is a country that will enthrall and surprise you at every turn. Hike up the famous Table Mountain. Go on a luxury safari. Fly high in a hot-air balloon over the countryside. Re-visit the place Nelson Mandela made history—the choices are aplenty on your South African vacation.

thingsToDo.name: Take a table top hike
thingsToDo.text: Hike up the famous Table Mountain for the stunning views and vistas. Don’t want to walk? Take a five-minute cable car ride all the way to the top.

thingsToDo.name: Say hello to African penguins
thingsToDo.text: Head to Boulders Beach, Cape Town and get up close to the only species of penguins acclimatized to the warm South African climate.

thingsToDo.name: Tour the Winelands
thingsToDo.text: Take a trip through the scenic and historic Cape Winelands, with exquisite wine tasting at local farms in Paarl, Stellenbosch, and Franschhoek.

thingsToDo.name: Try a balloon safari
thingsToDo.text: Watch the balloons being prepared on the field, then climb aboard with your pilot, and it's up, up, and away! Enjoy a bird’s eye-view of the beautiful valley.

thingsToDo.name: Go on a world-famous safari
thingsToDo.text: Head to Kruger National Park for a chance to see the 'Big Five': lion, leopard, buffalo, elephant, and rhino, as well as an astounding diversity of other wildlife.

places.name: Cape Town
places.description: Trace the legacy of Nelson Mandela and learn about Cape Town’s history of apartheid at Robben Island and the District Six Museum. Bustling Greenmarket Square is known for its buskers and for its selection of African crafts. Taste fresh-caught tuna, try Cape Malay cuisine, or sample African flavors that span the continent at the city’s restaurants.

thingsToDo.name: Reflect on the History of Apartheid
thingsToDo.text: Nelson Mandela was held captive during apartheid at Robben Island. Today, the island has a museum with exhibits on this dark chapter of South African life. Former inmates lead the tours. Visit District Six Museum for more apartheid history.

thingsToDo.name: Swim with the Penguins at Boulders Beach
thingsToDo.text: See the colony of African Penguins at Boulders Beach and maybe go for a swim.

thingsToDo.name: Find African Art and Handicrafts at Greenmarket Square
thingsToDo.text: The bustling stalls of Greenmarket Square offer a range of unique African souvenirs.

thingsToDo.name: Visit the Victoria & Alfred Waterfront
thingsToDo.text: Restaurants, nightly music, cocktails, and the Two Oceans Aquarium can be found at this bustling shopping destination.

places.name: Western Cape
places.description: The Western Cape is known for its rugged coast, incredible wildlife, and rich history. Soar to new heights with a ride to the summit of Table Mountain on the Aerial Cableway, or lace up your hiking boots and trek one of the mountain’s many trails. Journey to Cape Point where you can admire breathtaking views of the Cape of Good Hope and learn about the Cape’s significance to maritime history.

thingsToDo.name: Visit Table Mountain National Park
thingsToDo.text: Enjoy spectacular views from the summit of Table Mountain, which you can access by cable car or by hiking, and then travel to Cape Point at the Cape of Good Hope for stunning views.

thingsToDo.name: Stroll the Kirstenbosch National Botanical Gardens
thingsToDo.text: View indigenous species as you stroll the winding paths of this botanical garden.

thingsToDo.name: Dive with Sharks in Gansbaai
thingsToDo.text: Gansbaai is known as the Great White Capital of the world. See the sharks from the safety of the boat, or if you’re feeling adventurous, dive with the sharks in a cage.

thingsToDo.name: Whales and Dolphins at Tsitsikamma National Park
thingsToDo.text: See dolphins and whales at this national park that boasts diving, snorkeling, kayaking, swimming, sailing, and even bungee jumping opportunities.

name: Tanzania
description: From Mt. Kilimanjaro and Zanzibar, to the vast Serengeti, a visit to East Africa's largest country is sure to delight. You'll find nature's most majestic wildlife, the planet's most incredible landscapes, and the continent's most welcoming people in Tanzania. Whether you’re in search of “The Big Five” or the stunning Wildebeest Migration, you'll be spoiled for choice when choosing a safari. Plus, the idyllic beaches and the centuries old Swahili culture add to its magic.
weather: The climate is diverse with two rainy seasons.
bestTimeToVisit: June-September when it’s cooler and dry is considered the popular season for animal-sighting.

thingsToDo.name: Meet the Chimpanzees
thingsToDo.text: See the protected chimpanzees, made famous by primatologist Jane Goodall, in the forests of Gombe Stream National Park.

thingsToDo.name: Head to the Ngorongoro crater
thingsToDo.text: Check out vast herds of wildebeests, zebras, gazelles, buffalo, and their predators, the big cats as they roam the crater floor.

thingsToDo.name: Catch a sunset at Serengeti National Park
thingsToDo.text: See the landscape turn red and gold by the setting sun, silhouetting the wildlife around you.

thingsToDo.name: Take a hike
thingsToDo.text: Climb Mt. Kilimanjaro with a guided tour or just soak in its majestic presence.

places.name: Unguja
places.description: Once trodden by sultans and British imperialists, the capital of Stone Town here bursts with coral-stone forts, Persian palaces, and European frontispieces. And then there are the beaches, from seaweed-spattered Kendwa to whiter-than-white Nungwi and its salt-washed bungalows on the shore.

places.name: Mount Kilimanjaro National Park
places.description: A reserve that surely needs no introduction, the exotic reaches of the Mount Kilimanjaro National Park have been a symbol of Africa’s rich biodiversity and eye-popping backcountry since they were first inaugurated by the German colonists back in the 1920s. Today, they magnetise backpackers and intrepid walkers, who flock to strap on the hiking boots and scale the summit of Africa’s highest peak.

places.name: Ruaha National Park
places.description: Sprawled out over an area almost exactly the size of Wales, the Ruaha National Park has expanded and expanded over the years to become the single largest game reserve in the entire of East Africa. Today, it ranges more than 20,000 square kilometers over baobab forests, gallery woods and acacia-dotted plains. And despite its size, Ruaha’s relative inaccessibility ensures there are no booming crowds of safari-goers here. Instead, the game experience is up-close-and-personal, with cheetahs and leopards and wild dogs all part of the action.

places.name: Selous Game Reserve
places.description: UNESCO-attested and hailed by loyal safari-goers the world over, the Selous Game Reserve is a real monster of an area. It encompasses no less than 54,000 square kilometers in the heart of south-eastern Tanzania, and boasts a biodiversity to match. There are hippos in the ox-bow lakes, swaying baobab trees, wandering elephants at the mud fords, marauding wild dogs, and Cape buffalos to name just a few of the eye-catching fauna.

places.name: Pemba Island
places.description: As of yet undiscovered Pemba sits out in to the swells of the Indian Ocean, picking up on the tropical beauty front where the white beaches of the Swahili Coast left of on mainland Tanzania. A part of the same island chain as impossibly-beautiful Zanzibar, the spot comes imbued with some of East Africa’s most colourful coral gardens, each teeming with a kaleidoscope of marine life.
